column1: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has urged people to start wearing masks again as the country steps up surveillance of Covid cases.The prime minister called for increased testing and encouraged a return to Covid-appropriate behaviour. India had relaxed its Covid rules
column3: earlier this year after a drop in infection levels.The country witnessed two deadly waves in 2020 and 2022 - and the government had come under heavy criticism for its handling of the second wave in the summer of 2021 when thousands died amid a lack of oxygen supplies and critical medicines.At Thursday's meeting
column4: Mr Modi asked states to ensure operational readiness of hospital infrastructure
column5: including a healthy supply of oxygen cylinders and ventilators.While there was no reason to panic
column6: the prime minister cautioned against complacency and urged citizens to take all necessary precautions. The cases - three in Gujarat state and one in Odisha - were detected in July
column7: September and November and the patients have recovered
column8: health officials have said.Several experts have said that India does not have reason to panic.In Delhi
column9: Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal has assured the people that no case of the Covid variant has been detected in national capital.In the southern state of Karnataka
column10: the government has made Covid tests mandatory for flu-like symptoms and said masks may soon be mandatory in closed spaces.Top health officials have asked people to get vaccinated and take booster doses. Over 2.2 billion Covid vaccine doses have been administered so far in the country
column11: but only 27% of the population have taken the booster dose - which India calls a "precaution dose" - so far. The government said it had no plans yet to stop flights from countries where new cases were reported. But the country has resumed random testing of international travellers at the airports.On Thursday
column12: India's health minister Mansukh Mandaviya said in parliament that though cases in China were rising
column13: those in India were "depleting". He added that the ministry was closely monitoring new variants and advised states to increase genome sequencing.On Twitter
column14: the government also debunked a fake message circulating on WhatsApp regarding a subvariant of the Omicron strain.Mr Mandaviya also asked states to encourage people to follow social distancing and other rules during the upcoming festive season. Chief ministers of several states have been reviewing their preparedness to deal with infections if needed.
